s1.title: Overview
s1.p: This section contains several documents about developing real-world web applications with Cocoon.

Cocoon has different modules/concepts for making this task much easier. There are components for Session handling, the authentication framework , the portal framework and the newer portal engine. You will find these components in the latest SVN version of Cocoon. The documentation listed in the menu conforms to the current SVN version.

s1.title: Introduction
s1.p: A session is a data storage which resides on the server and records information about one single user. Cocoon creates a session on demand and from that point of time the user is tracked and information can be stored inside the session. Each following request of this user is linked to the one specific session, so there is always only one session per user on the server.

To avoid a fast growing amount of sessions on the server and the overcome potential security problems, a session has usually a valid period of time. If during this period no new request comes in from the user, the session object on the server will be destroyed by the server (this period of time is called session timeout). The web application often allows a user to explictly destroy a session.
The usual web applications create sessions during login of a user and destroy them when the user logs out.
